QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 20 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Trade Commission posts have (a) opened, (b) closed down since March 1983.
(2) What plans are there to (a) establish new Trade Commission offices and (b) separate existing Trade Commission offices from Embassies.
(3) What will it cost to (a) establish these new posts and (b) separate existing Trade Commission offices from Embassies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During the period between March 1983 and the establishment of the Australian Trade Commission in January 1986, a Post in Shanghai has been opened and the Johannesburg Post closed.

(2) (a and b) Pursuant to the powers vested in the Australian Trade Commission under its Act and in the exercise of its commercial judgment, the Australian Trade Commission seeks to focus its resources in geographical regions with the greatest market potential for Australian exporters. In that context, Austrade is currently reviewing the disposition of its overseas resources with a view to achieving their most effective allocation.

As publically announced recently, Austrade has concluded a review of its operations in the Middle East and Western Europe. Arising from that review was a decision to open a new Trade Commissioner Post in Dubai and expand the scale of its Post to Riyadh.

Australia-based staff from the former Posts at Kuwait, Abu Dhabi and Bahrain are being redeployed to new Posts and other regions where there is a greater potential to increase exports of manufactures and services.

In the future, Austrade's operations in the Arabian Gulf region will be centred upon Riyadh but with local support being provided by the existing Post at Jeddah and the newly opened Post at Dubai. The three Posts will be linked by modern data processing equipment to ensure that Australian exporters are provided with an efficient service that is of a scale compatible with the current market prospects in the area.

Austrade will be appointing a Trade Commissioner for the Eastern Mediterranean who will service Israel, Turkey, Greece and Cyprus. Competent marketing staff will, where necessary, be engaged locally to work to that Trade Commissioner; current activities of locally engaged staff in Tel Aviv and Athens will be maintained. In consequence, the former Trade Commissioner in Tel Aviv has not been replaced.

In Western Europe, Austrade's Posts at London and Paris will be strengthened and the Bonn Post transferred to Frankfurt. Frankfurt and Paris will have a greater area of responsibility than previously and along with London will be linked by data processing equipment to Posts such as Stockholm, The Hague, Brussels and Madrid which, it is intended, will in due course be managed by locally engaged marketing experts rather than Australia-based Trade Commissioners. The nature of Austrade's representation in Italy is under consideration with Austrade.
These changes will result in a strengthening of market research and a better operational focus within both the Middle East and Western Europe.
A similar review is currently being made of Austrade's resources in the Americas. I anticipate that the Managing Director of Austrade will shortly announce the results of that review.

(3) (a and b) The Commission is satisfied that the changes outlined above represent a more cost effective deployment of resources than previously existed and comply with its legislative responsibility to provide its services as efficiently and economically as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 16 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What restrictions apply to the number of vessels fishing inside Australian east coast waters and, in particular, of the NSW coast.
(2) Which foreign countries have vessels fishing in these waters.
(3) Are there restrictions on the number of Australian vessels permitted to operate in domestic east coast waters, especially off the NSW coast.
(4) What limits apply to the length of lines permitted for (a) foreign vessels and (b) Australian vessels.
(5) What charges are levied on foreign fishing vessels.
(6) How many licences does (a) a foreign vessel and (b) an Australian vessel require.
(7) How many foreign vessels are presently licensed to fish in Australian waters off the NSW coast, and what restrictions apply to the area within Australian waters that may be fished.
(8) What measures are taken by government authorities to ensure that the rules and restrictions applied to foreign vessels are observed by those vessels.
(9) With which government agencies, federal or state, does responsibility lie for the regulation and policing of Australian vessels in Australian waters off the NSW coast.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) (3) and (7) The number of Australian fishing vessels and any operational restrictions applying to fishing within the territorial sea are the responsibilities of the respective State/Territory Governments. Beyond that the Commonwealth is generally responsible for fishing activity, out to the limit of the 200 nautical mile Australian fishing zone (AFZ).
There are approximately 4700 and 3500 boats licenced to operate off Queensland and New South Wales respectively. Of these about 3100 are also licenced to fish in Commonwealth waters.
At present there are restrictions on the issue of new Commowealth fishing licences for operations in developed fisheries.

In addition to Australian fishing boats, Japanese tuna longline vessels are permitted to operate in specified AFZ waters, including some waters adjacent to the east coast. There are no other foreign fishing boats permitted to operate in those waters. The Japanese boats fish under the terms and conditions of annually negotiated access agreements and under the current agreement up to 290 are permitted to fish in the AFZ. The agreement specifies the areas of operation but generally those foreign boats are permitted to operate off the east coast of mailand Australia north of Latitude 34 degrees south. The Japanese longline fleet is also permitted to operate in AFZ waters around Tasmania. No foreign fishing is permitted within territorial seas and Japanese boats may not operate within approximately 50 nautical miles of the NSW coast during January to March (from Sydney to Coffs Harbour).

As noted above up to 290 Japanese vessels may be licensed but in 1985/86 only 265 Japanese boats applied to be and were so licensed. Of those, only 154 operated in the AFZ. The foreign vessels are licensed to operate in the areas specified in access agreements and there are no areas allocated to particular boats. In respect of Japanese fishing in waters adjacent to NSW some 80-100 vessels operate during the peak of the season.

Japanese vessels, like all foreign vessels which operate in the AFZ (ie. from the Republic of Korea and Taiwan), are required to adhere to a range of reporting requirements designed to safeguard the interests of the Australian fishing industry and to protect the marine resources of the Zone. They are also required to place Australian observers aboard as requested.

Foreign fishing vessels operating in the AFZ are subject to Australian law but there are no additional constraints on their operations beyond those specified in the agreements. The usual reason for operational restrictions is either to protect fish stocks or to prevent instances of gear conflict (ie cases in which foreign fishing interferes with domestic operations). The tunas which constitute the target species of the east coast longlines are classified as ``highly migratory species'' which are taken not only in the AFZ but throughout the region. In the case of southern bluefin tuna, restrictions on access in the AFZ have been imposed because of scientific concern about depletion of the stocks. The exclusion of Japanese long- liners from most AFZ waters south of latitude 34 degrees south and the implementation of global catch quotas reflects our concern at the heavy fishing effort applied to that species.

We have always consulted with State/Territory Governments and industry organisations prior to and during access negotiations and, since the proclamation of the AFZ in 1979, areas available to foreign fleets have been progressively reduced as the Australian fishing industry has expanded its range of operations.

With respect to the Australian fishing fleets the two main fisheries off the east coast-the East Coast Trawl Fishery and the South Eastern Trawl Fishery-are both subject to management plans with approximately 180 boats permitted to operate in the South Eastern Trawl fishery and some 1200 in the East Coast Trawl Fishery.

(4) There are currently no limits applying to the lengths of lines which may be used by Australian or Japanese vessels operating off the NSW coast. In respect of Australian vessels, while there are at present no restriction on line length, management arrangements for the east coast yellowfin/bigeye longline fishery are under consideration. While the East Coast Tuna Management Advisory Committee has yet to make its recommendations I would expect that gear restrictions (such as the maximum line length) will be an option examined.

(5) Foreign fishing in the AFZ may be classified as either bilateral or joint venture. All foreign fishing vessels are liable to pay an access fee, a vessel fee of $35/metre overall and a master fisherman's licence fee of $20. In some cases, such as that of Japanese longline operations under the bilateral agreement, the vessel and master fisherman's licence fees are subsumed in the total fee paid.

Joint ventures, that is, fishing operations which involve Australian and foreign partners, may provide wider benefits to the Australian community and under the Fisheries Act the Minister for Primary Industry is empowered to waive all or part of the access fee.
Access fees are usually based on a negotiated percentage of the landed value of the catch in the major market. In 1985/86 the access fee paid by Japan was $2.25 million; in 1986/87, $3.15 million.

(6) Under the Commonwealth Fisheries Act, 1952 Australian and foreign fishing boats required a Commowealth Fishing Boat Licence and the person in charge of a fishing vessel, operating in Commonwealth waters, must hold a Master Fisherman's Licence. Boats operating within State waters may be required to hold State fishing licences and marine authorities may require boat operators to hold other licences which are not related directly to fishing activities.

(8) Foreign fisherman who operate in the AFZ do so subject to their compliance with a range of reporting requirements involving logbooks, positions/catch reporting etc. Means of ensuring that foreign vessels adhere to specified conditions include primary surveillance by RAN and RAAF vehicles as well as secondary surveillance by Australian fishing vessels, merchant ships, commercial aircraft etc. I have already referred to observers aboard foreign fishing vessels.

(9) The New South Wales Department of Agriculture is responsible for administration of the regulations in respect of the fishing operations of Australian vessels in the territorial sea while the Australian Fisheries Service of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry assumes that the responsibility for fishing operations in proclaimed waters beyond the territorial sea and out to the limit of the AFZ.
Other authorities may cover the non fisheries-specific aspects such as navigation (Commonwealth Department of Transport) and survey and safety requirements (State Marine Boards, etc).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the nuclear power station at Ignalina in Soviet Lithuania is of a similar design to the Chernobyl nuclear reactor.

(2) Is he able to say whether studies by the Swedish State Power Board show safety margins at the Ignalina facility to be smaller than those in operation at the Chernobyl plant at the time of the nuclear disaster; if so, what representations has the Government made through the International Atomic Energy Agency to rectify the situation in light of the Government's comments following the Chernobyl disaster.
(3) If no representations have been made, why not and will they now be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The nuclear reactors at the Ignalina Power Station are of a type designated RBMK-1500. The type is a development of the RBMK-1000 reactor which was involved in the accident at Chernobyl. Appendix 1 of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's report on the Chernobyl accident, ``The Chernobyl Nuclear Accident and Its Consequences'', tabled in both Houses of Parliament on 24 September 1986, contains background on the Ignalina Power Station.

(2) and (3) An internal report by the Swedish State Power Board has suggested that the safety margins against a melt-down at Ignalina are probably very small, and that the design, as with other RBMK type reactors, would not meet Swedish safety requirements. The report has no official status, and is of a tentative nature, relying on the few technical details publicly available. It is understood that the State Power Board has not been able to obtain sufficient information from the Soviet Union to be able to verify the report's assumptions and modelling.

Given the speculative and tentative nature of the report, it would be inappropriate for the Australian Government to make representations to the Soviet Union at this stage. It is in the first instance for Sweden to decide on possible follow-up action.

Australia took an active role in international action in the wake of the Chernobyl accident to encourage additional action on nuclear safety. At an International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) meeting of experts to review the Chernobyl accident held in Vienna on 25-29 August, the Soviet Union tabled a detailed report on the accident sequence, the reasons for it and its consequences, and demonstrated a readiness to answer additional detailed questions on the accident. The Government hopes that the Soviet Union, and other countries operating nuclear facilities, will maintain and extend the provision of safety-related information on nuclear facilities to assist in the overall development of an improved nuclear safety regime.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The High Court Case of Koowarta v Bjelke-Petersen arose from a proposal by the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission to purchase the Archer River Pastoral Lease for the Winychanham group resident at Aurukun and elsewhere in Queensland. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 23 October 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What assurances has he given the leaders of (a) the pig industry and (b) veterinary organisations that the Canadian Government will be asked to conduct trials on the presence of transmissible gastroenteritis in its pigmeat exports.

(2) Will there be no changes made to present importation arrangements for uncanned Canadian pigmeat imports until it is proven beyond any doubt that these imports will be totally free of transmissible gastroenteritis.
(3) Does transmissible gastroenteritis pose a danger to human health.
(4) Is there evidence of transmissible gastroenteritis in nations other than Canada and USA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In answer to representations I have received from the pig industry and veterinary organisations, and following a meeting with their representatives, I advised both the Australian Pork Producers Federation and the Australian Veterinary Association (AVA) that I had asked the Canadian agricultural authorities to undertake transmission trials to establish whether transmissible gastroenteritis could be present in the meat of slaughter age pigs in Canada. The Canadian Minister for Agriculture has since advised me that they see no value in such trials as they would, in their view, be time consuming, expensive and unlikely to add to current knowledge of the disease.

(2) In considering the latest advice from Canada, and following discussions with industry, the AVA and scientific staff from the Australian Animal Health Laboratory (AAHL) I have asked my Department, in conjunction with industry and AAHL, to consider the feasibility and desirability of organising transmission trials at AAHL. If no agreed experimental protocol, which would advance the knowledge of transmission of TGE and assist in decision making, can be developed, I will decide on the importation on the basis of available evidence.
(3) No-my advice is that TGE does not pose a risk to human health.
(4) TGE is endemic in many major pig producing countries including most of Europe and Asia, Mexico and some South American countries in addition to the USA and Canada.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In its April 1986 Economic and Rural Policy Statement, the Government announced that the relationship between the proposed Horticultural Marketing Corporation and the three existing marketing authorities responsible for apples and pears, canned deciduous fruits and dried vine fruits would be resolved in consultation with the industries involved. In September 1986, the Department of Primary Industry published a discussion paper entitled New Commercial Structure for the Horticultural Industries outlining ways in which the proposal for establishing the Horticultural Marketing Corporation and related institutions may be implemented and the horticultural industries were invited to comment on the paper's contents.

Since then, consultations with many industries have taken place and are continuing. In particular, representations have been made either to the Department or to me by organisations within the apple and pear, canned fruit and dried fruit industries. It is expected that the initial round of consultations between my Department and industry organisations will be concluded soon. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 13 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did discussions take place between officers of his Department and Qantas on the most appropriate content and presentation of the drug warning film prior to its production; if not, were there any discussions prior to the formal request for Qantas to screen the film.
(2) What is the present position with respect to the film.
(3) Will the film be shown on flights other than those operated by Qantas; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Discussions with Qantas were initiated over one year ago, involving the Government's Advertising Service, my department and the advertising agency which was to produce the film, and included two special presentations to Qantas' Manager of Inflight Entertainment. An independent market research evaluation of the video was prepared specifically to assess the impact on in-flight audiences and this evaluation was conveyed to Qantas.

These consultations culminated in a letter from my department to Qantas' Manager of Inflight Entertainment, which advised him of my approval of the film and enclosed the script. Qantas replied raising only details of timing and payments. It was reasonable to understand from this exchange of correspondence that Qantas had no difficulty with the film content; the film was made.
The specific dates of these events were:
18 March 1986-market research report passed to Qantas
My department was, therefore, surprised to be informed at a meeting on 11 September 1986 that Qantas then found the film unacceptable.

(2) The film, which is suitable for showing as a community service, not only for in-flight screening to airline passengers on flights out of Australia, but also for showing domestically on television and in cinemas, was launched at a press conference on 14 October by Dr Blewett, the Minister for Health, and myself. There has been a gratifying response from television stations throughout Australia to the screening of the film in community service timeslots and the Greater Union Cinema chain is showing it in four States and the A.C.T.

(3) Officers of my department and the Government's Advertising Service have asked MAS, Garuda, Philippines Airways, Singapore Airlines and Thai International if they wish to screen the film on a non-commercial charge basis. Resident Australian missions in those countries have been briefed so that they can discuss this approach with local authorities. Cathay Pacific Airways have been approached on the same basis. I might mention also that the Canadian and Malaysian administrations have shown interest in using the film for their own drug warning campaigns.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Soviet Activity on Ballistic Missile Defences

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Age on 31 October 1986 entitled ``Soviets' guilty secrets are the key to SDI deadlock''.

(2) Is he able to say whether (a) the USSR has been experimenting with anti-satellite satellites since the late 1960s, commencing just as the US was abandoning its own early attempts in this direction, (b) the USSR persevered in a long series of tests with ``killersat'' satellites and (c) by the early 1980s the USSR had developed an operational, although limited, system.
(3) Is he able to say whether the USSR holds an advantage in ``Star Wars'' technology in that it possesses the world's only operational anti-ballistic missile defence system around Moscow.

(4) Is he able to say whether (a) the USSR is now expanding and improving this anti-ballistic missile system and equipping it with high-acceleration interceptor missiles, (b) construction of the Krasnoyarsk ballistic missile tracking station (i) is being accelerated and (ii) will violate the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty and (c) this system may be capable of locating and destroying low-orbiting satellites as well as some incoming missiles.
(5) Is he able to say whether the USSR has already built 2 large ground-based lasers that can hit low-orbiting satellites.

(6) Is it a fact that in (a) 1982 the then Soviet military chief of staff, Marshal Ogakov, indicated that the USSR was trying to create arms for space, citing a rapid advance in electronics and development of weapons based on new physical principles, (b) May 1985 the Soviet Defence Minister, Marshal Sokolov, admitted that Soviet scientists were trying to perfect early-warning reconnaissance, communication and navigation systems in space, (c) 1985 General Chervov admitted that experimental lasers existed and (d) 1972 the then De- fence Ministers, Marshal Grechko, told the USSR Presidium that the anti-ballistic missile pact places no limitations on the conducting of research and experimental work directed towards solving the problem of defending the country from nuclear missile strikes.
(7) Is he able to say whether the Soviet laser program (a) is much larger than the American program and (b) involves more than 10,000 scientists and engineers at a cost of $1 billion (US) per year.

(8) Does sufficient direct and circumstantial evidence exist to suggest that the USSR has taken its ``Star Wars'' initiative further than the laboratory research to which it insists on confining the US.
(9) What approaches has the Government made to the (a) US and (b) USSR in relation to constraining the development of space weapons systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) Yes, although the Government understands that the United States had two ground-based direct intercept anti-satellite systems in operational or semi-operational status at Pacific island locations until the mid 1970s. The Government further understands that these two systems were also in part a response to United States concerns in the late 1960s that the Soviet Union was developing a fractional orbital bombardment system (FOBS);

(c) According to the official United States publication Soviet Strategic Defence Programs, published in October 1985, the United States considers that the Soviet Union's co-orbital anti-satellite system became operational in the early 1970s.

(3) There is no dispute that the Soviet Union possesses the world's only operational anti-ballistic missile defence system, centred on Moscow. This system is permitted by the ABM Treaty and, as required by the Treaty, it is fixed and ground-based. It is not the Government's impression that the existence of this system means that the Soviet Union holds an advantage in ``Star Wars'' technology. ``Star Wars'' concentrates on advanced technologies such as directed energy devices like lasers and kinetic energy systems of sufficient accuracy to allow a conventional warhead or no warhead at all. The existing Soviet system continues to employ ground based missiles with nuclear warheads, as did the system which the United States discarded in the mid 1970s.

(4) (a) The Soviet Union does not normally make such information available but according to Soviet Strategic Defence Programs, (pp. 7-8) the Soviet Union has been upgrading the Moscow anti-ballistic missile system since 1980 with new radars, an improved version of the existing long-range exo-atmospheric interceptor missile and a new short-range, high acceleration interceptor missile. The total number of launchers for interceptor missiles has been increased from 64 to 100, the maximum number permitted under the ABM Treaty.
(b) (i) the Government is not in a position to say whether construction of the Krasnoryarsk radar has been accelerated.

(ii) the Government has stated that it believes the Soviet Union has a case to answer in respect of United States allegations that the Krasnoryarsk radar violates the ABM Treaty. It has urged the Soviet Union to demonstrate compliance with that Treaty.
(c) The Government understands that any system capable of locating and destroying incoming missiles could also destroy any satellites that come within its range.

(5) The Soviet Union does not normally make such information available but according to Soviet Strategic Defence Programs (p. 16) the Soviet Union has ground-based lasers that could possibly damage some sensors on US satellites.

(6) (a) It would be more accurate to say that General Ogarkov advocated the development, among other things, of credible ballistic missile defences and anti-satellite weapons and implied that the Soviet Union was working on such systems.

(c) No record of this particular quotation has been found but lasers, both experimental and operational have been in existence in all industrially advanced countries for many years. They have widespread civilian as well as military uses.

(7) (a) The Government is not in a position to compare the size of the laser programs in the United States and the Soviet Union. According to Soviet Strategic Defence Programs (p. 12) the Soviet research program into advanced technologies for defence against ballistic missiles represents a ``far greater investment of plant space, capital and manpower'' than is the case with Strategic Defence Initiative. Clearly this comparison includes but is not confined to laser programs.

(b) The Soviet Union does not normally make such information available but the Government is aware of US estimates that the Soviet Union's laser program involves over 10,000 scientists and engineers and if conducted in the US, would cost roughly US$1 billion per year (Soviet Strategic Defence Programs, pp. 12-13).

(8) It is difficult to give a definitive answer for at least three reasons (i) the secrecy which surrounds Soviet activity in this field; (ii) the vagueness to date of the Soviet proposals as to what activity it seeks to have confined to laboratories and what it understands in this context by the word ``laboratory''; and (iii) the fact that the ABM Treaty allows work on ballistic missile defences-including work on systems based on new physical principles-to be taken further than the lab- oratory provided the systems are fixed and ground-based.

(9) The Government does not endorse the SDI or what it considers to be a comparable program in the USSR. The Government has taken this position because it saw grave risk that the vigorous pursuit of strategic defences at the present juncture would inhibit the conclusion of new agreements to reduce the offensive nuclear forces and lead to the competive development and deployment of weapon systems for use in space. The Government is strongly opposed to the extension of the arms race into outer space. Apart from expressing these views publicly and directly to both the United States and the Soviet Union, the Government has urged them to reach an accommodation on these matters before irrevisible steps are taken. The Government has urged full and demonstrable compliance with the ABM Treaty and, has suggested, an extended period of non-withdrawal from the Treaty and negotiations to bring up-to-date the understandings on what activities can be pursued under the Treaty. The Government takes some encouragement from the fact that these propositions now form part of the agenda of the negotiations between the US and the USSR.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 28 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the approximate annual gross expenditure by farm producers on agricultural chemicals.

(2) What proportion of cash costs does agricultural chemicals represent for the industry, (a) wheat industry, (b) all grains industries, including wheat, (c) cotton industry, (d) fruitgrowing industries and (e) all primary industries.
(3) What tariffs were applicable to imported chemicals used on-farm as at 1 January 1986 and what revenue was being raised from these tariffs.
(4) What tariff levels will apply as at 1 January 1987 and what revenue is this expected to raise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It was recently estimated in the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report on `The Chemicals and Plastics Industries', 30 May 1986, that around 70 per cent of agricultural chemicals are sold to the rural sector, suggesting a market with a value of about $220m in 1983/84.

(2) In 1983/84, expenditure on agricultural and veterinary chemicals made up almost 5 per cent of total farm cash costs on average, with wheat about 6.5% and horticulture (including fruitgrowing) about 6.7%. (See Table A14.5 prepared by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics (BAE) and included in the IAC report at page 420). In addition BAE survey data indicate expenditure on agricultural chemicals within the cotton industry in 1983/84 at 16.6% of total farm costs.

(3) The general rate of tariffs which applied to imports of finished chemicals and primary chemicals (used in further processing), which appear under several tariff items, ranges between 0 to 30 per cent.

Revenue figures for tariffs raised on imported chemicals used on farms are not available. The classification of tariff items tends to be compound specific rather than end use descriptive and as agriculture chemicals comprise a number of chemical compounds, listed under separate tariff codes, calculations of revenue would require considerable resources.

(4) On 1 January 1987 tariff levels will be the same as currently applies. However, the Minister for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce announced on 30 October 1986 that a reduction in tariff rates to a level of 15% or below, would be phased in over a three to five year period from 1 February 1987. Some tariff levels currently below 15% will be increased to either 10 or 15% to eliminate certain anomalies.
The changes which have been announced are expected to reduce the overall level of tariffs on imported agricultural chemicals by some $2-4 million.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heri- tage and Environment, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has he taken to encourage the recipients of Commonwealth funding for the performing arts to perform Australian work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Access to Australian works in the performing arts is an important element in the development of our cultural identity. I strongly support initiatives taken by the Australia Council to encourage their production and performance, details of which are outlined below.
The Board pursues the Australian content objective in all styles of music.
Support for Australian performances commences with assistance for Australian composers which has increased from $136,000 in 1983 to $423,000 in 1985.
At the same time, the Board increased support to the Australian Music Centre, which has the task of promoting Australian composers. In 1986 the Centre received grants totalling $278,515.
In performance, the Board gives emphasis to supporting groups which specialise in the performance of contemporary works, especially Australian works.

In addition, the Board encourages all other applicants to include a proportion of Australian content appropriate to their activities and it has informed the music community that the size of grants is affected by the level of Australian content.

In community music, the Board supports a composer in residence in the community program. It has also funded musicians in residence programs, for instance in folk music, in which song writing skills are passed into a community and encouragement is given to express local concerns through song.

In accordance with the Board's Australian content objective, The Australian Opera has begun a consistent and continuing program of performance of Australian works, and it presented two full small scale works in 1985, plus a national opera ``workshop'' to test out new works (planned now to be offered annually). In 1986 it has presented the full main-stage production of Voss. The company has also commissioned a new music theatre work for 1987.

As its main policy objective, the Board supports theatre arts which relate to the Australian experience. A major example of this policy is the Board's support of the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust's Australian Content Program which has been funded since 1982 and in 1985-86 it received $214,000 for a program which facilitated performances of several Australian productions, both in Australia and overseas.

This Board also provides support and encouragement for the performance of Australian work in the area of community theatre and music projects. Examples of recent such projects are the residency by the Theatre South company in the Southern NSW town of Eden, to develop a play relating to themes about the area; and the touring theatre program by Mainstreet through rural South Australia.

This Board encourages the performance of the best professional work to emerge in theatre, dance and music among Aboriginal people. The Board supports traditional dance and music through grants for ceremonial activities and community festivals in tribal areas. Non-traditional/contemporary performing arts activities are supported through: assistance to the Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Scheme to conduct a national dance training school; grants for theatre script development, workshops and production activities; and funding for Aboriginal country music festivals.
Liaison with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation

In addition, the Australia Council has worked with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to develop a policy statement on the arts. This policy statement gives priority to, amongst other things, encouraging Australian composers and musicians through presentation in performance, competitions and orchestra workshops.

Another organisation within my portfolio concerned with the performing arts-the National Institute of Dramatic Art (NIDA)-encourages the performance of Australian works. NIDA conducts a part-time course for playwrights and at the end of each year plays emanating from this course are performed by the students. NIDA has also commissioned two new Australian plays for 1987 and 1988 and graduating actors performed in a production of ``Golden Age'' by Louis Nowra, a major Australian play, in August 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Commonwealth and State programs exist to encourage the purchase and/or commissioning of works of art as part of public building programs.
(2) What sums were spent by the Commonwealth during 1984-85 on the acquisition or commissioning of works of art for (a) new and (b) existing Commonwealth buildings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth encourages the purchase and/or commissioning of works of art for public buildings in a number of ways.

Artbank, a program administered by the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, promotes the development and appreciation of Australian art by the acquisition of art works by Australian artists. The works of art acquired are made available to clients by rental for display in locations accessible to the public, such as Government offices and private business throughout Australia and Australian overseas posts.

In 1984-85 a total of 438 new works were acquired by Artbank for a sum of $319,000. 90% of the total 3,456 piece Artbank collection was on hire at the end of 1984-85 and the rental income generated for the year was $275,000.
In 1984-85 Artbank spent $33,850 on the purchase of artworks requested by client Government departments for display in new Commonwealth buildings.

The Department of Housing and Construction may make provision for works of art in new Commonwealth buildings to a maximum of 0.5% of project cost subject to agreement by the client and approval by the Government. There is close consultation with Artbank in the case of portable works of art and with the Australia Council in the case of fixed works.

The National Capital Development Commission makes provision for works of art in appropriate public buildings and places as part of the integrated development of Canberra. Such works are located in areas where they will be accessible to a maximum audience across the community.

In consultation with the Australia Council and the Department of Housing and Construction, the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment is reviewing current arrangements with a view to encouraging greater use of art works in public buildings.
The Commonwealth does not have details of possible State Government programs to encourage the purchase and/or commissioning of works of art as part of public building programs.
(2) My Department has sought advice from all other portfolios on the sums spent by the Commonwealth during 1984-85 on the acquisition or commissioning of works of art for Commonwealth buildings:
(a) in 1984-85 approximately $1,113,000 was spent by the Commission on the aquisition or commissioning of works of art for new Commonwealth buildings; and
(b) in 1984-85 approximately $129,875 was spent on works of art for existing Commonwealth buildings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether residents of Queensland pay State taxes on (a) liquor, (b) petroleum and (c) tobacco.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) Australian Bureau of Statistics' Government financial estimates, (b) Commonwealth Grants Commission reports and (c) State budget papers indicate that residents of (i) Victoria, (ii) N.S.W., (iii) South Australia and (iv) Western Australia pay more tax per year than residents of Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes. Queensland levies a tax on retailers of liquor of 8 per cent of the value of their purchases in the previous financial year. Wholesale spirit merchants pay a licence fee of $400 plus 12 per cent of the value of liquor sold to unlicensed persons in the previous financial year (8 per cent on liquor sold to holders of a booth permit). The levy on sales by registered brewers to unlicensed persons is 12 per cent of the value of sales in the previous financial year (8 per cent on liquor sold to holders of a booth permit). There is a flat fee of $20 for a bottler's licence.
(1) (b) and (c) Queensland does not levy taxes on retailers/wholesalers of petroleum or tobacco.

(2) (a), (b) and (c) On the basis of the latest information, taxation receipts per capita are lower than in the other States referred to, although non-tax receipts, for example from rail freight receipts, are generally higher in Queensland than in the other States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 30 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government abandoned the concept of a statutory environmental contaminants authority; if so, why.

(2) Will the Environmental Contamination and Co-ordination Division in his Department be involved in the National Health and Medical Research Council inquiry into allegedly hazardous agricultural chemicals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An Environment Contaminants and Coordination Division has been established within the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment. This Division is developing and implementing, in conjunction with other Commonwealth and State government agencies, the range of functions which are envisaged in the Federal Platform of the Australian Labor Party for an Environmental Contaminants Authority.
It is not considered appropriate to establish at this stage a statutory authority to perform these functions.

(2) I am unaware of an inquiry by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) into allegedly hazardous agricultural chemicals. However, I am advised that the NH & MRC, which advises the Minister for Health, reviews potential hazards of agricultural chemicals as new information becomes available. The current review of organochlorine pesticides is an example of this process. My Department has recently taken on the role of environmental assessment of agricultural chemicals notified under the national clearance system operated by the Australian Agricultural Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 18 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When are states who are party to the World Heritage Convention due to pay their contributions to the World Heritage Fund.
(2) Did the 1985 and 1986 Budget appropriation permit Australia to pay its contributions to the Fund by the due dates.
(3) When did Australia pay its contributions to the Fund over the last 5 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the 9th Session of the World Heritage Convention (2-6 December 1985), the World Heritage Committee considered that more active measures should be taken to ensure that contributions to the World Heritage Fund be made by State Parties on a more regular basis than in the past in order to allow it to plan its activities more effectively. Accordingly the Director-General wrote to all State Parties to the World Heritage Convention on 20 and 24 March 1986, inviting them to pay their contributions to the World Heritage Fund, at as early a date as possible in each calendar year. In the case of Australia's contribution, Unesco requested that it be paid in two instalments during the biennium with each instalment representing the contribution for the respective calendar year.

(2) The 1985-86 Budget appropriation was sufficient to enable payment of the 1985 contributions. The 1986-87 Budget appropriation had to be supplemented to enable payment of the 1986 contribution. It should be noted, however that even with the requirement for additional funds the 1986 contribution was paid at approximately the same time of year as the 1984 and 1985 contributions.
(3) The Australian contribution to the World Heritage Fund over the last five years was paid on the following dates.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Ombudsman Report: Industrial Sugar Mills Case

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken on Special Report No. 2 by the Commonwealth Ombudsman on the Industrial Sugar Mills case involving the Department of Defence.
(2) Is it a fact that the Government cannot accept the revenue implications of agreeing to the recommended payment of compensation; if so, why.
(3) Have the revenue implications been calculated; if so, what is the calculated amount and on what basis has it been made.
(4) Have there been other incidents similar to the ISM case; if so, what were the (a) contracts (b) amounts involved.
(5) Has he noted paragraph 26 of the Ombudsman's report.
(6) Are there particular classes of administrative deficiencies for which redress should not be available; if so, what are they.
(7) If not, why does the Government refuse to accept the Ombudsman's recommendation.
(8) What action has been taken to ensure that the act of obvious negligence to which the Ombudsman referred in the ISM case is not repeated.
(9) On what basis did the Deputy Crown Solicitor advise that the Commonwealth bears no legal liability in this case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the right honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Action on Special Reports to Parliament made by the Ombudsman under section 17 of the Ombudsman Act is a matter for the Parliament and not the Executive.
I note that on 22 August 1986, the Senate referred both the Ombudsman's Special Reports to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for consideration.

(2) As I stated in my letter of 19 December 1985 to the Acting Ombudsman, (reproduced at Attachment 3 to the Ombudsman's Special Report No. 2), the Commonwealth cannot responsibly accept additional standards of liability which do not fall upon the Australian commercial community in general; and that it is not unreasonable to suggest that if compensation were paid in this case, there would be created a general expectation that the Commonwealth is prepared to compensate in similar cases.

(4) I understand that the Department of Finance is aware of a number of similar instances. It is not necessarily the case that all such instances are reported either to that Department or to my own Department or to the Ombudsman.

(6) The redress available for administrative deficiencies subject to the Ombudsman Act is clearly spelt out in the Act. Under that Act, such redress includes investigations of complaints, reports and recommendations to departments or authorities under section 15; the furnishing of information to the Prime Minister with regard to such reports under section 16; and the forwarding of such reports to the Parliament under section 17. Action taken on Ombudsman recommendations or reports will depend on the facts and surrounding circumstances of each case.
(7) The reasons are spelt out in my letter of 19 December 1985 to the Acting Ombudsman (see Attachment 3 to Special Report No. 2).

(8) I understand that the Department of Defence has taken steps to ensure that a situation similar to what occurred in the ISM case does not arise in the future. I am advised that an instruction has been issued in that Department to ensure that comparative statements of tendered prices and other information are double-checked against original tender documents.

(9) I understand that in relation to the particular aspects of the matter put to the Deputy Crown Solicitor, the basis of his advice was that, as no contract had ever been formed, no liability in contract had arisen. Moreover, I understand that in relation to those same aspects the Deputy Crown Solicitor did not consider that Commonwealth liability in negligence arose because of:
an absence of duty of care in normal commercial tendering situations;
an uncertainty of the extent of liability for negligence in the exercise of statutory powers;
the unlikelihood of recovery for economic loss where no physical damage arises; and
the absence of compensable damage suffered by ISM.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 26 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Did he state, on 12 August 1986, that the Commonwealth would offer redeployment to as many of the staff of the Australian Council for Inter-government Relations (ACIR) as possible; if so, is it a fact that (a) not one single member of ACIR's staff has been offered redeployment by the Commonwealth and (b) these persons are all now unemployed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In a letter of 12 August 1986 to the Premiers, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and the President of the Australian Council of Local Government Associations I noted that the Commonwealth would offer redeployment to as many of the staff of ACIR as possible but that the need for some compulsory retirements might arise.

In the event, legal and practical constraints limited the scope for direct assistance by the Commonwealth regarding permanent or ongoing temporary employment. Only one staff member was eligible for redeployment but elected not to exercise that right. His right of re-entry arose out of former employment in the Australian Public Service (APS). Under the relevant Public Service determination other staff could only be employed through selection for APS positions publicly advertised.

The Public Service Board (PSB) held discussions with staff of ACIR to provide assistance in identifying and pursuing available APS positions, and has continued to provide such assistance. The PSB also extended the closing date for Assistant Research Officer positions to enable ACIR staff to apply.
At the winding-up of ACIR all staff took advantage of the redundancy package approved by ACIR. Since then I am aware that at least one former staff member has obtained other employment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Does a Selstay scheme, under which an aged person sells his or her home for less than its full value and then leases back the property rent-free for life, disadvantage an applicant for a pension when the assets of the person are being assessed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is understood that there are various Selstay sale plans. These involve the arranged sale of the home at an agreed value to a private individual. The vendor receives a proportion of the sale price at the time of sale, a right to accommodation in the home for life or such shorter period as he or she wishes and payment of the balance of the sale price when vacant possession occurs. Rent is payable to the landlord throughout the period of residence.

On the information available, the scheme appears to involve selling the home, an asset which is exempt for pension purposes, for a consideration which includes the right to continue to occupy it for life. The security of tenure inherent in that right means that the pensioner would continue to qualify under the assets test as a home owner and accordingly the value of the right to occupy the home would be disregarded. Regard would be had to the deposit received if retained in the form of an assessable asset and a value would be placed on the outstanding debt.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated cost to his Department of the fringe benefits tax.
(2) What fringe benefits are provided by his Department and which officers of his Department receive them.
(3) How is the value of each of these fringe benefits calculated for tax purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An amount of $434,000 was provided in the budget estimates for payments in the 1986-87 financial year. This estimate is being reviewed in the light of the changes recently announced by the Treasurer and ruling issued by the Australian Taxation Office on the interpretation of the relevant legislation.
(2) The Department is liable under the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation for the following benefits:
(a) Housing provided to lightkeepers, staff located in designated remote localities and staff occupying residences on Departmental property in capital cities for functional or operational purposes.

(b) Use of Commonwealth motor vehicles for private purposes at remote localities and garaging of vehicles at private residences by very senior officers or in other circumstances where suitable garaging facilities are not available at the office location.

(c) That portion of the cost of official entertainment/hospitality that can be attributed to Departmental officers. Official entertainment/hospitality is mainly undertaken by very senior officers in accordance with guidelines issued by the Department of Finance under the Audit Act 1901, contained in Finance Guidelines 13/1 to 13/14 and Finance Directions 13/1 and 13/2 of the Finance Manual.

(d) Those costs met by the Department for telephones in private residences of certain Departmental officers who usually, by reason of their functional responsibility, are required to provide specialist advice to the Minister or Executive, or who are nominated by the Department as out-of-hours contact points.
(e) Return air travel on an annual basis to the nearest capital city for lightkeepers (and their families) and other employees in designated remote localities.
(f) Education assistance provided to lightkeepers' dependents.

(g) Cost of providing spouse-accompanied travel for officers of the Senior Executive Service (SES). SES officers who travel domestically on a regular basis are allowed one spouse-accompanied trip per year. In addition under certain circumstances SES officers can become eligible for spouse-accompanied travel overseas.

(h) Other minor benefits including tropical clothing allowance for officers located in designated tropical areas and overseas equipment allowance for officers travelling or located overseas for specific periods.

(3) The value of the fringe benefits for assessing the tax liability will be calculated in accordance with the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation and rulings of the Australian Taxation office on the interpretation of the legislation.
